articles.title: The year politics became brainrot
articles.description: Political violence has become illegible, and increasingly, politics and language have too.

articles.description: A brief look back at the history of net neutrality and its impact on the internet.

articles.title: The Canon EOS R6 Mark III is great, but this lens is amazing
articles.description: The Canon EOS R6 Mark III is a solid camera, but the new RF-45mm f/1.2 lens is truly exceptional.

articles.title: This smart garden turned my black thumb green
articles.description: A smart indoor garden turns your plant into a work of art, and it's perfect for those with a black thumb. The Gardyn Studio 2 is a self-watering planter that uses AI to monitor and care for plants.

articles.title: LG is announcing its own Frame-style TV at CES
articles.description: LG will unveil a new Frame TV line at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, with prices starting at $999 for a 55-inch model. The new TVs are designed to blend into any room.

articles.description: Instagram's head Adam Mosseri has said that users cannot trust their own perceptions due to advancements in AI and images.

articles.title: Like the Woolly Mammoth
articles.description: Scientists have had to contend with a spate of misinformation this year about efforts to purportedly resurrect long-lost species like the woolly mammoth.

articles.title: Feed Is Dead
articles.description: Instagram head Adam Mosseri says, “People stopped sharing personal moments to feed years ago,” in aNew Year’s Eve postabout the future of the platform as generative AI produces more realistic-looking content.

articles.title: Leaked video shows the Galaxy S26 Ultra’s new camera island
articles.description: Samsung has leaked a video of its upcoming Galaxy S26 Ultra, showcasing a new camera island.

articles.title: Aflac says a data breach impacted 22.65 million of its customers
articles.description: In June,Aflac discloseda data breach involving a “sophisticated cybercrime group” that stole names, social security numbers, contact information, health data, and more from its systems. The insurance provider hasnow revealedjust how many people are affected, adding that it is currently “not aware of any fraudulent use of personal information.”
